commands.name: Step 1: Create Namespace
commands.command: kubectl create namespace scenarios --dry-run=client -o yaml | kubectl apply -f -
commands.explanation: Creates namespace for network policy testing.
commands.next_step: Deploy backend application to test network policies.

commands.name: Step 2: Deploy Backend
commands.description: Deploy backend app, service, and NetworkPolicy
commands.explanation: Creates backend deployment with label 'role: api', a service to access it, and a NetworkPolicy that restricts access. Initially, without the policy, any pod can reach the backend. The NetworkPolicy will only allow pods with 'role: frontend' label.
commands.what_it_does: Creates backend-app deployment, backend-service, and backend-policy NetworkPolicy.

commands.name: Step 3: Check Backend Pods
commands.explanation: Should see 2 backend pods in Running state. These will be our protected backend that we'll control access to.
commands.next_step: Test connectivity from unlabeled pod (should be blocked).

commands.name: Step 4: Test Access (Unlabeled Pod - Should Fail)
commands.command: kubectl run test-unauthorized --rm -i --tty --image=busybox:1.28 -n scenarios -- wget -qO- --timeout=2 http://backend-service || echo 'Connection blocked as expected'
commands.description: Test if pod without 'role: frontend' label is blocked
commands.explanation: Creates temporary pod without any role label and tries to connect to backend. NetworkPolicy blocks this because the pod lacks 'role: frontend' label. Should timeout/fail.
commands.what_it_does: Attempts HTTP request from unlabeled pod (should be blocked by NetworkPolicy).
commands.next_step: Access blocked! Now test with authorized frontend label.

commands.name: Step 5: Test Access (Frontend Pod - Should Succeed)
commands.command: kubectl run test-authorized --rm -i --tty --labels=role=frontend --image=busybox:1.28 -n scenarios -- wget -qO- --timeout=2 http://backend-service
commands.description: Test if pod WITH 'role: frontend' label can access backend
commands.explanation: This pod has 'role: frontend' label, matching the NetworkPolicy allow rule. Connection should succeed with HTTP 200 response from nginx backend.
commands.what_it_does: Attempts HTTP request from frontend-labeled pod (should succeed).
commands.next_step: Access allowed! NetworkPolicy is working correctly.

commands.name: Step 6: Describe NetworkPolicy
commands.explanation: Shows podSelector (which pods the policy applies to: app=backend) and ingress rules (who can connect: role=frontend). This creates a security boundary - only frontend pods can reach backend.
commands.what_it_does: Displays full NetworkPolicy specification and status.

commands.name: Step 7: View Policy YAML
commands.command: kubectl get networkpolicy backend-policy -n scenarios -o yaml
commands.explanation: Shows the complete policy: podSelector targets app=backend, policyTypes: Ingress restricts incoming traffic, ingress allows from podSelector role=frontend. Default behavior is deny-all unless explicitly allowed.
commands.what_it_does: Displays NetworkPolicy as YAML for understanding structure.
commands.next_step: Test one more time to confirm behavior.

commands.name: Step 8: Verify Policy Enforcement
commands.command: kubectl run verify-block --rm -i --tty --image=busybox:1.28 -n scenarios -- sh -c 'echo Testing connection... && wget -qO- --timeout=2 http://backend-service || echo BLOCKED' | grep -E 'BLOCKED|HTTP'
commands.description: Final verification that unlabeled pods are blocked
commands.explanation: One more test to confirm: pods without the correct label cannot access the backend. This proves network segmentation is working.
commands.what_it_does: Attempts connection and confirms it's blocked.

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete All Resources
commands.explanation: Deletes all resources: backend deployment, service, and network policy.
commands.what_it_does: Removes all network policy scenario resources.
